tafseer.tafsir: In these verses, Allah says in the form of an oath against several angels who take human life violently and also to angels who take human life gently. This is in order to emphasize the existence of the day of resurrection which the polytheists deny. The following verses are also in the form of oath sentences to the angels who descend from the sky quickly carrying God's commands. Even Allah swore to the angels who preceded other angels with a bang, as well as the angels who govern the world. Words in the form of this oath are found in many Makkiyyah surahs because many polytheists reject and deny the resurrection day, such as in surahh as-saffat/37: 1-4: For the sake of (the entourage of angels) who line up in rows, for the sake of (the group) that prevents seriously, for the sake of (the group) that reads the warning, indeed, your Lord is truly One. (as-saffat/37: 1-4) As for the answer to the qasam (contents of the oath) at the beginning of surahh an-Nazi'at, it is found in verse 6, that is, when nature shook when the first trumpet was blown, everything was damaged and destroyed. The first trumpet blast is then followed by the second blast which raises people from their graves. This is Doomsday in the truest sense. The early verses in surahh an-Nazi'at are understood by the majority of commentators as oaths to the angels. However, there are other commentators, such as Ahmad Mustafa al-Maragi, who understand this oath not to the angels, but to the stars that revolve according to certain rules, such as the sun, moon and other planets. In the tafsir of al-MarAgi, these verses are understood as the stars that move quickly and swiftly, the light that comes out from star to star, and the stars that move quickly from other stars. As for the understanding of the qasam answer, it is the same as the opinion of the jumhur mufasir.

In these verses it is explained that the hearts of the disbelievers at that time were very afraid after they witnessed what had been told to them before in the world. The Meccan infidels when in the world had even been told directly by the Prophet Muhammad. Their eyes drooped limply, always looking down because of a very high fear and anxiety. In another verse the condition of the disbelievers on the Day of Judgment is described as follows: They come in haste (to fulfill the call) by raising their heads, while their eyes do not blink and their hearts are empty. (Ibrahim/14: 43)

In this verse it is then explained that the disbelievers who deny the day of resurrection ask with regret, "Are we really returned to the way we were before?" They also asked this question, as contained in the word of Allah: They said, "Is it true, when we have died and have become dust and bones, we will really be resurrected? (al-Mu'minun/23: 82) ) Even on the Day of Judgment they will still ask, "Will we be resurrected too when we become bones that are crushed and unite with the ground?" even though in the world it has been explained in the word of Allah: He said, "Who can revive the bones destroyed?" Say (Muhammad), "It is (Allah) who created it first. And He is All-Knowing of all creatures. (Yasin/36: 78-79)

In this verse they finally say, "In that case, we will indeed experience a very detrimental return." Allah answered their ridicule and regret by explaining that the return was quite simple, namely that it could only happen with one blow by the Angel Israfil. Finally they realized that humans cannot view the events of the resurrection day as impossible. Because, with that they can immediately live again on the surface of the earth as the beginning of the hereafter.

In this verse, Allah reminded the Prophet Muhammad about the story of Musa in the form of a question, namely whether he did not yet know about the story of Musa who was sent by Allah to Pharaoh to convey his message in a subtle and gentle way as stated in Allah's word: to him (Pharaoh) with gentle words, hopefully he is aware or afraid. (thaha/20: 44) The story of the Prophet Musa, especially when God calls Moses in the sacred valley, namely in the Thuwa Valley near Mount Sinai. At that time, Prophet Musa praised Allah as explained in the following verse.

(thaha/20: 44) The story of the Prophet Musa, especially when God calls Moses in the sacred valley, namely in the Thuwa Valley near Mount Sinai. At that time, Prophet Musa praised Allah as explained in the following verse.

The task of the Prophet Musa was to go to Pharaoh and advise him because Pharaoh had gone too far, acted arrogantly towards the Children of Israel and enslaved them with extraordinary cruelty and was beyond humanity. Among these were orders to kill male babies and let female babies live. Then God ordered the Prophet Musa to carry out the da'wah smoothly and gently. The Prophet Musa was ordered to have a good dialogue with Fir'aun and ask whether Fir'awn wanted to rid himself of error. Pharaoh had wallowed in error, so it was better to accept the guidance from Allah that was brought by the Prophet Musa. Pharaoh needed to take the path of virtue, namely to distance himself from evil deeds. Then the Prophet Musa was ordered to explain openly by inviting Pharaoh to follow his treatise towards the way of Allah by fearing Him.

Then Allah explained that Pharaoh remained disobedient and did not want to follow the invitation of the Prophet Musa so that Moses was forced to show his miracles. Then Musa showed Pharaoh a great miracle, that is, a staff that turned into a snake and palms that shone brightly. Even so, Pharaoh still denied the prophethood of Musa and remained rebellious and opposed to Allah. Then Pharaoh turned and tried to make resistance to Musa.

In these verses, Allah explains that Pharaoh gathered his superiors and called out to his people, some of whom consisted of sorcerers. With arrogance, Pharaoh said, "I am your most high god. Don't follow Musa's invitation."

In these verses, Allah explains that Pharaoh gathered his superiors and called out to his people, some of whom consisted of sorcerers. With arrogance, Pharaoh said, "I am your most high god. Don't follow Musa's invitation."

So Allah sent down punishment on him, not only in this world but also in the hereafter. The torment in this world is by being drowned with his people in the Red Sea, and the torment in the hereafter is by being plunged into the Hellfire, which is a very bad place to return to.

In this verse it is explained that actually in such an incident there is a lesson for people who have reason and can calculate every incident with its consequences, especially for people who fear Allah.

This verse urges humans to use their minds to compare their own creation which is small and weak with the creation of the universe which is so vast and sturdy. It shows the power of God. Ibn Khaldun describes the human condition that exalts logical abilities without sharpening their heart by saying, "How can a human with a brain that is only the size of a golden scale be used to weigh the universe?"

In this verse it is explained that Allah exalts the sky, expands it, and completes it with celestial bodies, such as planets and others. Allah then establishes provisions that govern the celestial bodies, so that they remain in place and do not fall, as if they were decorations for the entire universe. Creating and managing the universe (macrocosm) is much more complicated and complex than creating humans who are only called microcosms. Today's modern scientific studies state that the entire universe began with its formation from a singularity. Singularity is something where space, energy, matter and time candidates are still gathered into one (unified). The Big Bang exploded this singularity and it grew like a spiral-cone that was continuously expanding wider and wider. It was since the Big Bang that time began to separate itself from space, as well as energy, matter and forces to separate itself, and over billions of years the entire universe, which contains billions of galaxies, was formed. Space and time continue to experience widespread expansion. This is what is called "raising the building (the sky)". Bahiruddin S. Mahmud explained that the expansion of the universe is not infinite, not continuous. The rate of this expansion or development gradually decreases, because the gravitational force between galaxies (which they keep moving away from each other) begins to relax, so that one day the expansion of the universe will stop, then the building will be perfect.

In this verse it is explained that Allah has made the night pitch black and the day bright, and the alternation of day and night, and the difference in the seasons as a result of the circulation of the planets around their orbits. Regulating and maintaining the circulation of these planets is truly an extraordinary work.

It was also explained that Allah made the earth spread out, so that Allah's creatures could easily carry out life there. This verse shows that Allah created the earth first, then created the heavens, then returned to the earth and spread it out for human habitation. After preparing the places to live, then Allah provides everything that is needed by humans, namely regarding food and drink, as explained in the next verse.
In this verse it is explained that Allah emits from the bowels of the earth springs and rivers and grows vegetation, both for human and livestock food.
In this verse it is also explained that Allah fixed the mountains in a very firm way like pillars so as to make the earth stable and not shaken. Allah explains his wisdom in the following verses.

Everything is for the pleasure of humans and livestock. Thus, humans and animals can live in peace and earn a living by doing various activities. This is also explained in another word of Allah: He is the one who sends down water (rain) from the sky for you, some of it becomes drink and some of it (fertilizes) plants, to which you feed your livestock. (an-Nahl/16: 10) After studying the contents of these verses which are intended to convince about the existence of the day of resurrection, it should become material for reflection that God, who has created man and created everything necessary for his life, has lifted up the sky above and stretches the earth beneath, won't it have power to resurrect people on the Day of Resurrection? Is it proper that Allah allows people to do useless deeds after preparing the means for them and accumulating the abundant goodness for them?

In this verse it is explained that if a very big catastrophe, namely the Day of Judgment, has come that causes youth's hair to turn gray and hell can be seen, then everyone will forget the other calamities they have experienced. Allah will separate those who are obedient and pious, which will be put into heaven, and those who are disobedient and disobedient, which will be put into hell.

On the Day of Resurrection, humans will be reminded of what they did while living in the world, because their deeds are recorded in a complete book containing records of their words and actions from the time they grow up until they die.

As for those who are arrogant and exceed the limits, preferring the delights of the life of this world over the rewards in the hereafter. So verily Hell is the place of residence of Jahim.

The polytheists asked the Prophet when the Doomsday would come. They asked this in a mocking and scornful tone. The Prophet himself wanted to answer their questions correctly, but Allah forbade him because only He alone knows when the Day of Judgment will occur.

In this verse, Allah asks whether the Prophet Muhammad will mention the time of Judgment? Though his job is just to give a warning so there is no authority to mention about the arrival of the day of resurrection. The time of the Day of Judgment remains a secret of Allah. The Prophet himself did not know about the time of his arrival, as Allah says in the Qur'an: Your obligation is nothing but to convey (the message). (asy-Syura/42: 48) In a hadith narrated by 'Umar bin al-Khaththab, when the Prophet was asked about when the Day of Judgment would come, he replied: The person who is asked does not know more than the person asking. (Muslim history from 'Umar bin al-Khatthab) Allah keeps secret when the Day of Judgment comes and has great wisdom, namely that humans always prepare themselves at all times by doing lots of good deeds and always avoiding evil deeds.

In this verse it is explained that only Allah knows when the stipulation of time will be. No one knows when the stipulation of time, and when will happen the end of the world except Allah himself. Allah's Word: They ask you (Muhammad) about Doomsday, "When will it happen?" Say, "Indeed, the knowledge of the Hour is with my Lord; no one (one) can explain the time of its occurrence other than Him. (The Hour) is very heavy (commotion for creatures) in the heavens and on earth, will not come to you unless suddenly." They ask you as if you know it. Say (Muhammad), "Surely the knowledge of (the Day of Judgment) is with Allah, but most people do not know." (al-A'raf/7: 187)
In this verse it is explained that the Prophet Muhammad was only assigned to warn people who fear the resurrection day. They are asked to prepare themselves by doing good and avoiding evil.

On the day of witnessing the day of resurrection and feeling its turmoil, they feel as if their stay in the world is only temporary, like a morning or an afternoon in those old days. Human life in this world is indeed only for a moment, as Allah says: On the day they see the promised doom, they feel as if they stay (in the world) only for a moment during the day. (al-Ahqaf/46: 35)
